III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not searching youth returning from home visit
Investigation I spoke to Complainant 1 on 7/28/23. No new information was
presented.
All interviews were conducted face to face at the facility on 8/1/23.
Administrator 1: Administrator 1 reported Youth A had a five-day
home pass with her foster home. When she returned, they found
pill bottle with her sister’s name on it. Administrator 1 reported
they took two vape pens and a marihuana pen from her two days
later. Administrator 1 reported they did not find the pens on her
but other residents made comments about them so they then
began questioning and checking the home for those items. Youth
A was using the weed pen in the shower. Administrator 1 reported
they complete searches on the youth when they come back from
home visits. Administrator 1 reported that they “pop bras”, check
overnight bags, purses and have the youth turn their pockets
inside out.
Youth A: Youth A reported she went on a home visit and
accidently brought her sister’s pill bottles. Youth A reported that
staff checked her bags and found the bottles. Youth A reported
she has had the vape and marihuana pens since summer school
in mi July. Youth A reports she placed the pen in the metal of her
bra and staff, even with searching can’t find it. Youth A reported
she was smoking during shower time and staff got suspicious and
took it from her.
Youth B: Youth B reported Youth A brought the two vape pens
and one marihuana pen back from her most recent home visit.
Youth B reported they smoked the marihuana pen together and
the staff knew something was “off” with them. Youth B reported
the staff questioned them and searched their rooms. Youth B
reported staff didn’t find the marihuana pen at first but then later
found it. Youth B reported that Youth A was searched when she
came back from her visit, but the staff did not find it. Youth B
reported staff search them every time they come back from an
outside activity.
I reviewed Incident Report #1 dated 7/26/23. All information is
consistent with the above interviews. Youth A returned on 7/25/23
2

from her home visit. The agency was given information on 7/26/23
that Youth A might have vape pens. That day they completed
room searches and could not find anything. They also had a
conference call with the foster parents and case manager where
Youth A denied having all items.
I reviewed Incident Report #2: Youth A was told she would be
searched again. Youth A then took the vapes out of her bra and
gave them to staff.
I reviewed Incident Report #3: Staff was given information that
the two vapes were not the only pens in the house. Staff
questioned Youth A when she had completed her shower. Youth
A then gave the marihuana pen to staff from her dirty clothes in
the shower room.
I reviewed the policy concerning searches from home visits:
…the Girlstown staff reserve the right to search you and your
belongings and/or collect urine sample for a random drug screen if
it is warranted to do so…
Analysis Both youth reported staff completed searches for this particular
return from Youth A’s home visit and reported staff do them
regularly. Staff were able to find the pill bottles from their search
but not the vape and marihuana pens. When they were given
information that these were in the home, they reacted quickly and
searched the rooms and contacted necessary parties to address
the situation.
Consultation: The agency has a search policy but it does not go
into the particulars of how to conduct one, or where to search, or
what to search. The agency may want to spell out those specifics
within their policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
